Award.AwardTitle: Adjoint tomography of the crustal and upper-mantle seismic structure beneath Continental China
Award.AbstractNarration:
East Asia has drawn much attention of geoscientists due to its complicated zoo of tectonic activities: unique continent-continent collision of India and Asia, different styles of plate subduction, various types of hydrocarbon-bearing basin formation, widespread intracontinental rifting, intraplate volcanism and magamatism. Tracing the driving forces behind these tectonic activities is vital to understand how the ancient continental roots, continental and oceanic plates at the plate margins, and mantle flows underlying lithosphere interact amongst each other in a dynamic earth framework. It?s essential to obtain high-definition multi-parameter seismic images of the earth?s interior to test different hypotheses of the tectonic driving forces, such as crustal shortening or/and Indian plate underthrusting causing the uplift of ?the world?s roof?, the Tibetan Plateau, lower-mantle plume or/and dehydration from the stagnant slab in the mantle transition zone (410 ? 650 km depths) inducing hot mantle upwelling contributing to the intraplate volcano Changbaishan along the border of China and North Korea, and the Pacific slab subduction and rollback producing extension, transtension, and thinning of the lithosphere beneath the East China and opening of the marginal seas of Japan and South China. Seismic imaging in this study will map full waveforms of seismic records to render more realistic models representing the earth?s interior properties. The outcome will not only provide the independent and robust seismological constrains to test the end members of tectonic formation mechanism, but also shed new light on the composition, thermal state, flow and fabric structure of the lithosphere and upper mantle, which are complementary to geological, geochemical, petrological, and geodetic observations of East Asia.

An unprecedented seismic waveform dataset recorded by very dense array stations in China and its surrounding regions will be used to image the crust and upper-mantle structure beneath the East Asia. This dataset is comprised of seismic records from the CEArray, the NECESSArray, the INDEPTH-IV Array, F-net and other global and regional seismic networks. Contrary to traditional ray-theory based seismic imaging, adjoint tomography of this study takes into account full 3D wave propagation effects and off-ray-path sensitivity. In this implementation, it utilizes a spectral-element method for precise wave propagation simulations. The tomographic method starts with a 3D initial model that combines the smooth radially anisotropic mantle model S362ANI with 3D crustal model Crust2.0 (potentially recently released Crust1.0 can be used for more accurate and higher resolution model refinement). Traveltime and amplitude misfits are minimized iteratively based on a conjugate gradient method, harnessing 3D finite-frequency kernels computed for each updated 3D model. The massively parallel simulations are carried out on XSEDE supercomputers available to the team via an existing XSEDE research allocation. The final models will allow close examination of seismic structures beneath different tectonic units of East Asia, and better understanding of how sub-surface processes shaping surface geology and tectonic features. The preliminary results already show strong correlations between heterogeneities in the crust and upper mantle with surface tectonic units, such as the Himalaya Block, the Tibetan Plateau, the Tarim Basin, the Ordos Block, and the Sichuan Basin. Narrow slab features emerge from the smooth initial model above the transition zone. 3D wavespeed variations in the preliminary model are either comparable to or sharper than high-frequency P- and S-wave tomographic images from previous studies. Additional iterations will be carried out to refine the 3D radially anisotropic models, and to resolve 3D azimuthal anisotropy and attenuation, which are closely related to mantle rheology and crustal and lithospheric strain rates and flow. This proposal will support one graduate student and one research scientist. The outcome of this research will also have a broader impact on understanding the linkage between 3D wavespeed heterogeneities and seismogenic processes. The more realistic high-definition models will help assess seismic hazard by providing more accurate ground motion maps, more robust slip predictions and rupture estimations on finite fault surfaces for future catastrophic earthquakes. The final models will be archived and distributed for quantitative studies in other fields of geoscience, such as geology, geochemistry, petrology, geodynamics and volcanology. With the existing 3D visualization lab facility at Rice, the earth models can be readily displayed to the public to promote earth science. Finally the results will enhance scientific communication between US and China and broaden future potential collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate the driving forces behind the formation of high-topography features in the continent of East Asia. High-topography landforms, several kilometers above the sea level such as plateaus and domes, have significant impacts on regional climate and environment. They can exist in very different tectonic settings. For example, the Tibetan Plateau is located at a continental margin where the two continents, India and Eurasia, collide and converge, while the Hangai Dome is situated in a continental interior of central Mongolia, far away from continental margins where tectonic plates converges. In both cases, the mechanisms that led to their surface uplift are unclear. Whether and how the tectonic or mantle processes contribute to their formation is an on-going debate, partly due to seismic image discrepancies among previous studies. Differences in seismic tomography techniques and seismic data sets are the two main causes of image discrepancies. In order to obtain a high-resolution seismic model of East Asia, our team performed adjoint tomography on a large data set of waveforms recorded by a wide-aperture dense seismic array (mainly in China). Adjoint tomography, an advanced full waveform inversion based on spectral-element and adjoint methods, accurately maps the elastic properties of the Earth’s interior from full waveform measurements. Our project resulted a new three-dimensional radially anisotropic model of the crust and upper mantle beneath East Asia, namely EARA2014, which describes the elastic properties of the Earth’s media in terms of isotropic shear wave speeds, isotropic compressional wave speeds, and radial anisotropy, i.e., the wave speed difference between the two horizontally traveling shear wave that are polarized horizontally and vertically.

The new seismic images from EARA2014 reveal the following main findings. Beneath the Hangai Dome of central Mongolia, a localized deep mantle upwelling, characterized by low shear wave speed indicating a slightly warmer (54 K to 127 K) temperature, is inferred to have generated magma in the rigid shell of the Earth due to decompression melting. The heat released by the magma makes the lithosphere underlying the dome more buoyant that caused the surface uplift of the dome. On the contrary, beneath South-Central Tibet, a T-shaped high wave speed structure is interpreted as an upper-mantle remnant from earlier lithospheric foundering. We infer that Tibetan lithosphere has thickened and formed a denser root that broke away and sank deeper into the mantle. We conclude that most of the uplift across Southern Tibet likely occurred when this denser lithospheric root broke away. The new seismic images beneath these two continental high-topography regions imply very distinct mechanisms that lead to their formations. Hangai Dome is formed due to an active bottom-up asthenospheric upwelling, while the Tibetan Plateau is uplifted due to convective removal of thickened Tibetan lithosphere.

We produced a high-resolution tomographic model of East Asia (EARA2014). This new model is being used by researchers in seismology and other Earth Science disciplines for seismic reference model and for geodynamics and tectonic reconstruction of East Asia.The digital models of published work are currently being distributed through MSU Seismo Lab Website. Our research results are highlighted in news media, YouTube video, and TACC podcast and have reached a very broad public audience. This project provided funding support for one female research scientist (Dr. Min Chen) at Rice University who has transitioned to a tenure track assistant professor position at Michigan State University. This project also provided training or funding support for two Ph.D. students and two Masters students. Half of those are female students. Currently three students completed their degrees. One Masters student continued to pursue a Ph.D. in geophysics, the other is applying for Ph.D. program in the same field. The female Ph.D. student started to work as a research scientist in a research institute upon completing her degree. The other Ph.D. student is in his fifth year of the Ph.D. program.
